title: Conflict & Trust
description: Explore how conflict affects trust and how trust enables healthy conflict.

questions.text: For me, healthy conflict requires trusting that...
choices: My partner won't use my vulnerabilities against me
Conflict won't threaten our relationship
We can disagree and still love each other
All of these—trust is the foundation

therapeutic.rationale: Trust requirements for healthy conflict vary. Vulnerability-protectors need safety; relationship-security seekers need stability; love-despite-disagreement believers need acceptance. Without trust, conflict becomes dangerous.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these trust requirements are important. Ensure all are present for safe conflict.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust requirements create aligned understanding of what makes conflict safe.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What trust do you need to engage in healthy conflict? Is that trust present?

questions.text: After conflict, my trust in my partner is usually...
choices: Unchanged—conflict doesn't affect it
Temporarily shaken, then restored
Dependent on how the conflict went
Strengthened if we handled it well

therapeutic.rationale: Trust impact from conflict varies. Unchanged-types have stable trust; shaken-then-restored types recover; dependent-types evaluate; strengthened-types grow through conflict. Understanding your pattern helps you communicate.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust patterns may cause confusion. The unchanged-type may not understand the shaken partner's experience. Be patient with each other's processing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust impact pattern creates aligned post-conflict experiences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does conflict affect your trust in your partner? How do you rebuild it?

questions.text: Something that damages my trust during conflict is when...
choices: Things I shared in confidence are used against me
My partner says hurtful things they don't mean
I feel like they're not fighting fair
The relationship itself is threatened

therapeutic.rationale: Trust damage sources vary. Confidence-breach is betrayal; hurtful-words wound; unfair-fighting violates rules; relationship-threats create insecurity. Knowing what damages your partner's trust helps you avoid it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different damage sources require avoiding different behaviors. Learn and avoid your partner's trust-damaging triggers.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared damage sources create clear boundaries about what to never do.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What damages your trust during conflict? Has your partner done those things?

questions.text: Trust is rebuilt after conflict by...
choices: Consistent caring behavior over time
Genuine apology and changed actions
Talking through what happened
Time and experiencing safety again

therapeutic.rationale: Trust rebuilding approaches vary. Consistency-needers watch patterns; apology-needers want acknowledgment; talkers process verbally; time-needers restore naturally. Knowing what rebuilds trust helps repair.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different rebuilding needs require different effort. Learn what rebuilds trust for your partner specifically.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared rebuilding approach creates aligned repair efforts.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What rebuilds your trust after conflict? Are you getting that?

questions.text: I want conflict to ultimately build trust by showing that...
choices: We can handle hard things together
We're committed even when we disagree
We respect each other even in difficulty
We can grow through challenges

therapeutic.rationale: Conflict can build trust when navigated well. Handling-hard-things demonstrates capability; commitment despite disagreement demonstrates security; respect-in-difficulty demonstrates values; growing-through-challenges demonstrates development. Healthy conflict strengthens.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these trust-building outcomes are valuable. Conflict managed well provides all of them.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vision for trust-building through conflict creates aligned goals.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you want conflict to affect trust in your relationship?
